Rabies cases are increasing in northeastern Thailand.

Dr. Tawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office on February 9th clarified that the infection of rabies has increased in the northeastern part of Thailand in the last few months, and the number of infected persons has increased to a total of 74.
In this fiscal year (last October to September this year), 74 persons in total were positive for rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Phuket, 67 and 7 respectively.
All of them had received rabies vaccines in the past.
He urges people to get rabies vaccines along with hepatitis and not to touch the saliva of suspected infected animals.
Rabies is not only infected to humans from dogs, but also from cats and bats.
If a person is infected and develops the disease, it is almost 100% deadly, and it is necessary to prevent death by vaccination before the disease.

FUJI to Prevent Accidents Due to Left-Behind Vehicles, Develops System and Tests It on Own Vehicles|Chubu Keizai Shimbun
Fuji, a company that manufactures and sells robots and machine tools for assembly of electronic components, has developed a system to prevent children from being left behind in cars.
The system uses a human sensor installed in the car to detect human movements and send notifications to the phone or chat.
At present, demonstration experiments are carried out in shuttle vehicles of our own facilities.
It protects the safety of children, even though painful accidents due to abandonment occur.
At present, the demonstration experiment is carried out in two shuttle vehicles of the English conversation after school 'teracoya THANK' for children which the company operates in Chita City.
The human sensing sensors detecting human movement from the temperature difference between the person and the surrounding are installed in three places in the ceiling of the car.
When the vehicle's engine is turned off and the door is closed, and a person's movement is detected after a certain time has passed, a warning notification is automatically sent.
The system is able to prevent the error detection by linking the information with the status of the engine and the door.
The warning notification is sent through the crowd.
In addition to calling the number registered in advance, the message is displayed in the chat on the computer or smartphone.
The atlases are registered in a single database, and the atlases are stored in a separate database.
The demonstration experiment will be continued until the end of February.
"During the experiment, we also saw the peripheral problems other than the system," said Ichiro KAMINARI, head of the 2nd division of the innovation promotion department.
For example, the creation of an environment where drivers can concentrate on driving, and the collection of various issues related to school bus.
We are committed to spreading our solutions.
The development of the abandonment prevention system was prompted by the abandonment accidents of shuttle bus that occurred in a succession throughout the country.
Some employees with young children suggested that something should be done to protect the safety of the children.

The development was decided to take advantage of the know-how in information management using IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, which was cultivated through the business related to FA (factory automation).
The Fuji Anti-Lost System is easy to sell.
The sensor is installed by hanging it on the ceiling.
Since it is easy to be installed on a shuttle vehicle, the introduction of the harness is aimed at popularization.
In the future, the productization will be examined while asking for the cooperation with the nursery and kindergarten.

The construction of the Hokuriku Shinkansen from Tsuruga to Shin-Osaka, which was scheduled to start in the beginning of fiscal year 2023, has been postponed, and the urban development of the west of Tsuruga in Fukui Prefecture has begun to be affected.
In Kohama City, where the new station is to be established, the detailed location of the station is indicated even now, and the urban planning including the surrounding improvement is in progress.
The plan is considered to take a long time to be decided, and the publication is required as soon as possible.
The Hokuriku Shinkansen station planned for Kohama City will be the only new station west of Tsuruga.

In 1919, the Railway Construction and Transportation Facility Improvement Support Organization indicated a range of about 2.5 kilometers radius around JR Higashiohama Station as the location of the station.
The detailed station location and route determination were targeted for winter of 1922.
In the fiscal year 2001, the Shinkansen-related business in Kohama City was fully developed in view of the opening of Tsuruga and Kohama.
In the original budget for fiscal year 2022, the number of projects is further increased and the city planning is advanced with the prospect of the announcement of the location of the new station.
However, the detailed location of the new station is not shown.

The city has examined land use and improvement concepts based on the location of the new station, and has included 3 million yen in the budget for this fiscal year as a business to make a basic plan, but it is expected that it will not be executed.
The city plan centered on the new station "takes time to form the agreement of the citizens" (city responsible person).
It is expected that the new suburban stations in the prefecture that are not built in the existing JR stations, such as Echizen City, will require considerable time to complete the overall concept.
The more late the announcement is, the shorter the opening or preparation period, and the more the impact on the surrounding improvement is feared.
The extension west of Tsuruga is not clear before the new station.

In October last year, a group of citizens of Kyoto City on the extension route submitted a petition to the Ministry of Land, Transport and Communications requesting the withdrawal of the extension plan.

The Ishikawa Prefectural Government has been delaying the start of construction and demanding a rethink of the Yonehara route, and the route setting has been decided and the movements to return to the starting point have been repeated, so that it is difficult to say that the neighboring prefecture is a solid rock.

The citizens of Kohama are relatively calm about the postponement of the start of construction, and it is feared that the future of the station will be affected if the location of the new station is not known and the opening time is not clear.

The Mayor of Matsuzaki, Koji, has a policy to continue the request activity to the nation for early opening of the entire line, and the voice of the area along the line that demands early start of construction is indispensable.
The indifference that 'one day the Shinkansen will pass (west of Tsuruga)' cannot move the government or the neighboring prefectural government.
I want you to keep on raising your voice.

The ruins of Ushikehara-jo Castle, which was built to prepare for the battle with Hiraizumi-ji Temple = Ushikehara, Ono City, Fukui Prefecture
The Inukaikawa district of Ono City, Fukui Prefecture, where the large Ushikehara manor estate once stood.

Ushi-Kehara-jo Castle is said to have been built on the middle slope of Mt. Nabetsu in the district in preparation for a battle with Hiraizumi-ji Temple, which was in conflict with the shoen during the Kamakura period.
He appears in the military history story 'Taiheki'.
No records of Ushike-hara Castle have survived, but 'Echizen Ushihara Jito Jihadashi' (Echizen Ushihara Jito's suicide) in Volume 11 of the Taiheiki (Taipei Chronicle) states the following.
Tokiharu AIKAWA, a bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) official, was sent to Ono as a jito (chief of the village).

In 1333, the Rokura-tandai (a group of samurai who were appointed to monitor the Imperial Court and control the Western Provinces) was defeated by Takauji ASHIKAGA, and the Kamakura bakufu was destroyed by Yoshisada NITTA.
When the Toji family heard the news that the Rokuhara Tantai had been destroyed, they fled immediately, leaving only about 20 people.
The monks of Heian-ji Temple took advantage of this and attacked the temple.
Toji threw his wife and two children into the river and then committed suicide.

Echizen town has made a reflection note and distributed it to the townspeople who wish to receive it.

The reason for this is that many people came to receive the 'Okuyami Handbook', which covers the necessary procedures, a written list of inheritance, and a family tree for the death of a relative, last year.

In various places in the prefecture, lectures on how to write a reflection note and how to organize life are held frequently, and it seems that 'end of life' has become firmly established among the prefectural residents.
The entering note of Echizen town is 35 pages.

It begins with a review of the patient's history in five chapters, and then describes the patient's current health and financial situation, future care, hopes for terminal care, and requests for funeral and grave.
There are also sections for writing things that you want to do for the rest of your life and messages to loved ones.
It is not necessary to fill in all the pages, even if it is painful to write that there are 35 pages.
What do you want to leave behind to the people around you, apart from your family?
The important thing is to clarify the purpose.
A variety of notebooks are sold in bookstores for various purposes, and it is said that one should start writing at ease when one can write.
It was in 2009 that the word “enkai” was born.
The Great East Japan Earthquake occurred 11 years later.
It is said that many people have seen the reality that 'death comes suddenly' and therefore more people are preparing for their own death or terminal stage.
It's been over 10 years.
The new coronavirus pandemic that has hit the world has not yet subsided.
With the Russian invasion of Ukraine, prices have risen, and this winter electricity rates have jumped to unexpected levels.
On the other hand, many people are worried about the future, even though wages are higher than the current high prices.
On the other hand, the funeral expenses, care expenses, and the maintenance of the grave, which were once shared by the family and relatives, are now not unusual in the age of one-child.
And, the life span is greatly extended compared to a long time ago, and the risk of dementia and need care is increasing with increasing age.
It is important to keep in mind that the background of the establishment of the end of life as a temporary event is the increase of social anxiety.
However, it is the wish of everyone not to place an excessive burden on their partners or children.
"Make your own final moments" is a popular keyword in the Entenk゙ Note, and we should not be too solitary.
I would not write my wishes and requests in secret, but would consult with my family and prepare calmly for the time.

"From Tohirobo, "The Wavebreaker of Life," Dear Prime Minister" is a book published at its own expense by the non-profit organization "Hearing to the Heart Collection and Editorial Bureau."
The 10th book with the title 'Dear Prime Minister, From Tohiro Hibo, The Wavebreaker of Life' was published at our own expense.
The papers in Japan have covered the event, and many readers have sent their comments.

The purpose of this book is to share with you the contents of the interviews with suicide victims about the causes of suicide in Japan, the social and structural environmental problems, and to create a "good society".

We have been monitoring the rocky beaches of Higashihirobo, Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide site, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we continue to support those who attempt suicide by finding and protecting them and helping them to re-start.

This book is a compilation of issues heard from 784 people (2/6 as of now) whom I have protected so far, and it appeals to the Prime Minister regarding the following seven items of national measures necessary to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life saving" activities.
(2) "Human rights violations" are accumulated behind suicides.
(3) Suicide victims are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) The administrative institutions treat the citizens living outside their jurisdiction as "strangers" and treat them with disdain.
(5) Depressed mentally ill people are drugged and even if they commit suicide, it is treated as an "accident".
(6) The "duty to take care of safety" in high-risk areas of suicide is forgotten and commercialized.

(7) The doctrines of the new religious organizations that are not scientifically proven are deceitful, and the act of threatening the other person with a future evil and making him or her provide money is blackmail.
We should publicly announce and eliminate the religious organizations that are engaged in this criminal activity of "fraud and extortion."

The exhibition of the City Center for Cultural Heritage "Kanamaki" introduces the pioneers of plant research and also includes the collections of the Mount Hayashi-mine. |Iwanichi Online 岩手日日新聞社

An exhibition entitled "People who introduced the flowers of Mount Saiikee - A short history of the research on the plants of Mount Saiikee" is being held at the Municipal Integrated Cultural Heritage Center in Omu-cho, Kanagawa City, on December 12.
The collection of 124 items of valuable specimens collected by the author and the footprints of the author involved in the botanical research of Mount Hachiman are introduced.

The botanical research on Mount Hayashibe began with the Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximovich (1827-1891) who came to Japan at the end of the Edo period, and Naganosuke SUGAWA (1842-1925) from Shiba-cho who collected plants under Maximovich's guidance.
Maximovich, who was not allowed to travel freely in the country because of foreigners, asked Sugawa to collect and continued his research for three years based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

Sugawa continued to support Maximovich's research after his return to Japan, and this led to the publication of 'Himeko Sakura', 'Nanfutouuchiso', and 'Miyamayama Fukishouma', which are unique to Mount Hachiman.

After that, Tomitaro MAKINO (1862-1957), a modern botanical taxonomician, published 'Nanphutranoo', 'Kohanotsumeksa', and 'Nanphuinunasuna' in 1903, based on the collections of local researchers, and 'Katouhakohe' in 1905, which he discovered and named himself after climbing Mount Hachiman
From the exhibition materials, it is clear that many researchers have discovered valuable alpine plants.

This paper also introduces Matsunosuke SUGIMURA (1874-1948), who was the headmaster of Hanamaki Elementary School and who accompanied the survey for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927, and Shichiro TAMAKAWA (1914-1988), who was a curator of the Omu-machi Mountain Museum and who also contributed to the publication
Sohei YOSHIDA, a researcher in the field of Japanese Folklore at the same center, says, "There is a lot of research and connection between people behind the names of each plant in Mount Hachiman.

The exhibition is composed of four chapters, the first chapter is about the belief and history of Mount Hachiman, and the second chapter is about the features of Mount Hachiman from the geological point of view, based on the researches of Heinrich Ettemund Naumann (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundations of Japanese geology.

The opening event of the Okinagabu branch of the real estate web service "Sakasama Fudosan" which makes the desire of people to rent vacant houses and vacant shops and to try to rent them visible and which seeks landlords, was held on the 8th at the community center "entaku" in Chima, Chima-cho.
The operating company explained the outline of the service through the talk session.

The representative board member of Tsukinoha (Tosiri-gun, Hokkaido), who is responsible for the operation of the branch office, said that 'I hope that by doing this project on Okinabu Island, we can create a movement and a flow that will attract people to the whole island.'

In contrast to the usual real estate procedure, Sakasama Real Estate is a system where the borrower discloses his/her information and the lender contacts him/her, and the parties agree to sign a contract.

On-Co Co., Ltd.(headquarters in Mie Prefecture) operated the service as a demonstration experiment to excavate potential vacant houses and build relationships through vacant houses, and began the service in June, 2020.
The branch office was opened as the seventh branch office and the first in Kyushu.
This is the first time in Japan that a remote island has been visited.
About 20 people including staff of On-Co and Tsukinoha, Japanese guests, officials of the town hall of the two famous towns, and local residents participated in the event.

The representative board member of Okubo explained the background of the opening of the branch office as follows: 'As the movement to invite people from outside the island became more active, I thought that if we used vacant houses and vacant shops, the town and the island would be more lively from there.'
He said, "We want to connect with people who have properties on the island or who want to do something, and help them to advance the project one by one."

Takeshi MIZUYA, the president of On-Co, pointed out the following points to be taken into consideration when operating a community: "We need to take care of each vacant house, and we need to discuss with the locals how we want to develop this area, what kind of people we want to invite, and what criteria we should use to choose."

The islanders were invited to participate in the discussion and to cooperate in providing information, saying that "the deeper the connection between people, the deeper the information will be gathered."
